A benefit drag show for a brewery was postponed due to violent threats, after an individual commented on a Facebook post about the event stating "I will die before I let that take place" and "I'll be damned if I'll allow a pride celebration in my hometown of Brevard. They may as well consider themselves target practice," along with a photo of an automatic rifle.

Four individuals stole a Pride flag, destroyed property, and left behind a dead possum at a private residence. This was the second incident at this location.
Individuals associated with the National Justice Party, a white supremacist group, posted stickers that read: "White Strike."

An individual allegedly stabbed and killed another person in an anti-gay and anti-Black assault at a gas station after seeing the victim dancing. A group of men then approached the victim and told him to stop dancing while using anti-gay and anti-Black slurs. The victim confronted the men and was stabbed by one of the group members during the altercation.

Individuals associated with the antisemitic Goyim Defense League distributed propaganda on the windshields of parked cars that read: "Every single aspect of abortion is Jewish," "Every single aspect of Trump's campaign financing is Jewish," "Every single aspect of the Biden administration is Jewish" and "Who is behind the 'Rise' in transgenderism?"

Approximately 14 individuals associated with the neo-Nazi Blood Tribe and six individuals associated with the anti-LGBTQ+ extremist coalition Gays Against Groomers (GAG) protested a Pride in the Park / drag queen event. Blood Tribe carried swastika flags and a banner that read: "Stand with us or stand with pedophiles" and chanted: "No pedos in our streets," "There will be blood, blood, blood," "Us or the pedophiles," and "Pedophiles get the rope." GAG held signs reading "Drag is not for kids," "No child is trans" and "Pride is not for kids."

description: Approximately seven individuals associated with the white supremacist Dixieland Nationalist Club, Order of the Black Sun and White Lives Matternetwork held a roadside demonstration holding signs that read " White Lives Matter," "White flocks rock" and "DeSantis loves  White Lives Matter."
Approximately three individuals associated with California Blackshirts demonstrated near the corner of Highway 41 and El Camino. Members held a banner that read: "White men unite."
Individuals associated with Great Lakes Active Club, a white supremacist group, distributed propaganda that read: "Great Lakes Active Club United by Steel" and " White Lives Matter."

Approximately two individuals dropped a banner over an overpass that read "The Jews did 9/11."
Individuals associated with the National Justice Party, a white supremacist group, posted stickers promoting their group.

Approximately five individuals associated with the white supremacist  White Lives Matter Network held an anti-immigration protest. Members held signs that read: " White Lives Matter," "Protect the Historic American Nation" and "Save the Swans, End Immigration."
An individual associated with the white supremacist Church of Ben Klassen placed stickers and fliers in a public area that stated: "Say no to pedophilia" and "Fuck Jews."

Individuals associated with the antisemitic Goyim Defense League distributed propaganda that read: "Documentaries every patriot needs to watch," "Every single aspect of Child Sacrifice is Jewish" and "Every single aspect of Communism is Jewish."

Approximately 12 individuals associated with  White Lives Matter Texas, Patriot Front, Alamo Active Club and Parker County Active Club, all white supremacist groups, held a jointmeet up. The group later dropped a banner that read:  "White Lives Matter" and "Tribe, Train, Alamo AC."

Individuals associated with the antisemitic Goyim Defense League distributed propaganda that read: "Every single aspect of the Biden administration is Jewish," "Every single aspect of 9/11 is Jewish," and "Every single aspect of abortion is Jewish."
Antisemitic propaganda was left at a café. It read, in part: "The Bible is mostly a lie, the holocaust is entirely a lie, and Jews are known to deny their violent crimes."

The following was spray painted at a restaurant: "Hange the [n-word]s," "[N-word]," swastika were drawn in various locations, as well as penises.

An individual ripped down a Pride flag flying at a private residence. This occured two weeks after multiple Pride flags were vandalized and burned in the same area.

Approximately more than a dozen individuals associated with the National Justice Party, a white supremacist group, held a protest. The protest centered around Texas House Bill 1193 and Section 8 housing. Members held signs the read: "Protect our Families," "HB 1193, Anti-White" and "Section 8 Violence, GOP Silence."

group: 14 First,American National Socialist Party (ANSP),Aryan Freedom Network (AFN),New Columbia Movement,Patriot Front (PF)
description: Approximately 100 individuals associated with multiple white supremacist groups including 14 First, Aryan Freedom Network (AFN), Patriot Front, as well as the New Columbia Movement and the militia groups This is Texas Freedom Force and Texas Defense Force Security, gathered outside a church to protest a drag show. Protestors held "Save Our Children" flags and claimed they were protesting "the transformation of once-sacred spaces into purveyors of filth and degeneracy."

group: Active Clubs, New Jersey European Heritage Association (NJEHA)
description: Approximately nine individuals associated with the white supremacist Embrace Struggle Active Club and the New Jersey European Heritage Association (NJEHA) held a joint protest at the United Methodist Church. Members carried banner advertising the Embrace Active Club website and another that read: "Free Rundo."

Mauricio Garcia opened fire outside a mall, killing eight people and wounding seven more, before being shot and killed by police. Evidence on his body, handwritten diaries and online posts made by Garcia revealed that he, a dark-skinned Hispanic man, had a clear affiliation with white supremacist ideology. However, there is no clear evidence that the attack itself was motivated by his white supremacist beliefs.

group: Gays Against Groomers (GAG),Protect North Carolina Kids (PNCK)

Aimenn D. Penny of Alliance, Ohio was arrested for arson in connection with the firebombing of a church in Chesterland because the church hosted transgender-related events. Penny is associated with the Ohio chapter of the white supremacist White Lives Matter network and had recently taken part in anti-LGBTQ+ protests. Penny allegedly told police he wished his Molotov cocktails had been more effective and burned the whole church down.

Approximately 50 people associated with the white supremacist Groypers attended a "Fuentes Rally." During the event, white supremacist Nick Fuentes gave a speech against demographic and cultural changes to America, promoted Christian Nationalism and attacked the mainstream GOP. Fuentes also targeted "Talmudic Jews," a common white supremacist and antisemitic term for Jewish people.

U.S. Army Solider Noah Edwin Anthony was arrested on weapons charges for possessing a "ghost gun" and an illegal short-barreled rifle. Neither firearm had serial numbers. A subsequent investigation uncovered white supremacist materials, as well as evidence of a plot to "physically remove" as many racial minorities as possible from several North Carolina counties "by whatever means needs be." Anthony pleaded guilty in April 2023 to possessing an unregistered firearm.

Chase Allan was shot and killed by police during a traffic stop that started because of an illegitimate license plate. Photos show Allan's vehicle had a fake sovereign citizen plate. During the stop, Allan was uncooperative and used pseudo-legal sovereign citizen language. When officers attempted to remove Allan from the vehicle, a brief struggle ensued and ended with Allan being shot. Police say Allan was wearing a holster and a handgun was found on the driver’s-side floor of his car.

Federal authorities in New York unsealed murder-for-hire and money laundering charges against three men described as "members of an Eastern European criminal organization." Rafat Amirov of Iran, Polad Omarov of Eastern Europe and Khalid Mehdiyev of Yonkers, New York are accused of plotting the murder of U.S. citizen Masih Alinejad. Alinejad was being targeted by the Iranian government for criticizing the regime's human rights abuses. According to authorities, this is the second plot to kidnap or kill Alinejad originating from Iran in recent years.

Police shot and killed environmental activist and eco-anarchist Paez Terán after they allegedly fired a bullet that hit a Georgia State Trooper while officers were trying to clear protesters from the controversial "Stop Cop City Encampment." Experts say microscopic gunpowder residue found on Teran's hands indicated they recently fired a shot and, according to the Georgia Bureau of Investigation, a forensic ballistic analysis determined the projectile recovered from the officer's leg matched the handgun found in Terán's possession.

Tyler W. Massengil is accused of firebombing and damaging a Planned Parenthood clinic by throwing a Molotov cocktail through a window. Massengil allegedly said he wanted to hinder the clinic's ability to provide services. He was charged by federal prosecutors with malicious use of fire to damage the clinic.

Police arrested Solomon Peña for "masterminding" drive-by shootings at the homes of four local elected officials, all Democrats. The shootings occurred from December 4, 2022, to January 3, 2023. Peña called himself the "MAGA king" on social media and posted about election denial and QAnon, as well as "misogynistic, homophobic and transphobic statements." He ran as a Republican for the New Mexico State Legislature in 2022, but lost to a Democrat. Following the election, he visited three of the victims' homes to complain about ostensible election fraud and to demand the vote not be certified. He said that government officials in New Mexico "who helped overthrow Trump" were "treasonists" who needed to be sent to Guantanamo. Peña was incited in late January 2023 on 14 criminal counts, including conspiracy and shooting at an occupied dwelling.
